text: Grammar Checker Error List for C1 Cantonese ESL Speakers Article Errors Flag and Explain: Missing definite article: "I went to bank" → "I went to the bank" Missing indefinite article: "She is teacher" → "She is a teacher" Unnecessary article with plural generalizations: "The dogs are loyal animals" → "Dogs are loyal animals" Article with proper nouns: "The Hong Kong is busy" → "Hong Kong is busy" Article with abstract nouns: "The happiness is important" → "Happiness is important" Flag Only: Zero article with institutions (idiomatic): "She is at the home" → "She is at home" Plural Formation Flag and Explain: Missing plural marker: "five book" → "five books" Double plural: "many peoples" → "many people" Irregular plural: "childs" → "children" Uncountable noun pluralized: "informations" → "information" Asian-specific plurals: "staffs" → "staff" Verb Tense and Aspect Flag and Explain: Missing past tense: "I see him yesterday" → "I saw him yesterday" Simple past vs. present perfect: "I already finished" → "I have already finished" Present perfect with specific time: "I have seen him yesterday" → "I saw him yesterday" Progressive with stative verbs: "I am knowing the answer" → "I know the answer" Future with present simple: "I go tomorrow" → "I will go tomorrow" Past perfect confusion: "After I ate, I had gone home" → "After I ate, I went home" Flag Only: Present simple for habits: "He is always coming late" → "He always comes late" Subject-Verb Agreement Flag and Explain: Singular subject, plural verb: "She like coffee" → "She likes coffee" Collective noun agreement: "The team are winning" → "The team is winning" There is/are errors: "There is many people" → "There are many people" Neither/either agreement: "Neither of them are correct" → "Neither of them is correct" Word Order Flag and Explain: Adjective after noun: "shoes red" → "red shoes" Adverb placement with frequency: "I always am late" → "I am always late" Question word order: "Why you did that?" → "Why did you do that?" Indirect questions: "I wonder where is he" → "I wonder where he is" Negative inversion: "Never I have seen" → "Never have I seen" Preposition Errors Flag and Explain: Time prepositions: "at Monday" → "on Monday" Location prepositions: "arrive to the office" → "arrive at the office" Dependent prepositions: "discuss about" → "discuss" Transport prepositions: "by the bus" → "by bus" "Different from/than/to": "different than you" → "different from you" Flag Only: Phrasal verb prepositions: "look up it" → "look it up" Countable vs. Uncountable Nouns Flag and Explain: Quantifiers with uncountables: "many furniture" → "much furniture" "Less" vs. "fewer": "less people" → "fewer people" Amount vs. number: "amount of students" → "number of students" Uncountable treated as countable: "an advice" → "advice" or "a piece of advice" "Equipment/machinery/luggage" errors: "equipments" → "equipment" Pronoun Errors Flag and Explain: Missing subject pronoun: "Is very important" → "It is very important" Unclear antecedent: "Mary told Jane she was wrong" → needs clarification Reflexive pronoun misuse: "myself will attend" → "I will attend" Object pronoun as subject: "Me and him went" → "He and I went" Relative Clauses Flag and Explain: Missing relative pronoun: "The book I bought it is good" → "The book I bought is good" Extra pronoun in relative clause: "The person who he came" → "The person who came" Which vs. that: "The people which attended" → "The people who/that attended" Preposition position: "The house which I live in it" → "The house which I live in" Modal Verbs Flag and Explain: Double modals: "will can go" → "will be able to go" Modal + infinitive with "to": "can to do" → "can do" Past modals: "should went" → "should have gone" "Must" vs. "have to": confusion in different tenses Flag Only: Tentative modals for politeness: "You must attend" → "You should attend" (in casual contexts) Conditional Sentences Flag and Explain: First conditional tense: "If I will see him, I tell him" → "If I see him, I will tell him" Second conditional tense: "If I will be rich, I would travel" → "If I were rich, I would travel" Mixed conditional errors: "If I studied, I will pass" → "If I had studied, I would have passed" Gerund vs. Infinitive Flag and Explain: "Enjoy/finish/avoid + infinitive": "enjoy to swim" → "enjoy swimming" "Want/hope/decide + gerund": "want going" → "want to go" "Stop + gerund/infinitive": confusion between "stop to do" vs. "stop doing" "Remember/forget" patterns: semantic differences with gerund/infinitive Passive Voice Flag and Explain: Missing auxiliary: "The report written yesterday" → "The report was written yesterday" Wrong form: "The email was sent to I" → "The email was sent to me" Unnecessary passive: "The meeting was attended subjects: "My mother she is a teacher" → "My mother is a teacher" Topic-comment structure: "This matter I don't know" → "I don't know about this matter" Classifier remnants: "one piece of car" → "one car" Redundant "there": "There has a problem" → "There is a problem" "More/very + comparative": "more better" → "better" Flag Only: Measure word interference in formal writing Adjective Order Flag and Explain: Wrong adjective sequence: "Chinese old beautiful building" → "beautiful old Chinese building" Coordinate adjectives without comma: "big red" vs. "big, red" Negative Structures Flag and Explain: Run-on sentences: "I went home I ate dinner" → "I went home, and I ate dinner" Comma splice: "It's raining, I'll stay home" → "It's raining, so I'll stay home" Fragment: "Because I was tired." → "I stayed home because I was tired" Misplaced modifier: "Running quickly, the bus was missed" → "Running quickly, I missed the bus" Reported Speech Flag and Explain: Tense backshift: "He said he is tired" → "He said he was tired" Pronoun shift: "She said, 'I am ready'" → "She said she was ready" Time expression changes: "He said, 'I'll do it tomorrow'" → "He said he would do it the next day" Conjunctions and Connectors Flag and Explain: "Although...but": "Although it's late, but I'll stay" → "Although it's late, I'll stay" "Because...so": "Because I'm tired, so I'll rest" → "Because I'm tired, I'll rest" Run-on with coordinator: "I like tea I drink it daily" → "I like tea, and I drink it daily" Possessive Forms Flag and Explain: Missing apostrophe: "Johns car" → "John's car" Its vs. it's: "Its raining" → "It's raining" Inanimate possessives: "the door of the car" vs. "the car's door" Spelling and Commonly Confused Words Flag and Explain: Their/there/they're confusion What-cleft errors: "The thing what I need is..." → "What I need is..." It-cleft word order: "It was John who he came" → "It was John who came" Pseudo-cleft construction: "What I do is I go" → "What I do is go" Wrong emphasis structure: "It is that I need help" → "It is help that I need" Ellipsis and Substitution Flag and Explain: Missing ellipsis: "I can't play tennis, but she can play tennis" → "I can't play tennis, but she can" Incorrect substitution: "I have three books and she has three books too" → "I have three books and she does too" Inappropriate ellipsis: "Although tired, went home" → "Although tired, I went home" Flag Only: Overuse of full forms where ellipsis is natural Participle Clauses Flag and Explain: Dangling participle: "Walking down the street, the trees were beautiful" → "Walking down the street, I saw beautiful trees" Wrong participle form: "Been tired, I slept early" → "Being tired, I slept early" Missing subject match: "Having finished the work, the TV was turned on" → "Having finished the work, I turned on the TV" Present vs. perfect participle: "Finishing my work, I left" → "Having finished my work, I left" Subjunctive Mood Flag and Explain: Missing subjunctive after "suggest": "I suggest that he goes" → "I suggest that he go" Subjunctive with "insist": "She insists that he comes" → "She insists that he come" "It's time" structure: "It's time you go" → "It's time you went" "I'd rather" structure: "I'd rather you will come" → "I'd rather you came" "If I were" vs. "If I was": "If I was rich" → "If I were rich" Hedging and Boosting Flag and Explain: Inappropriate certainty: "This is the reason" → "This may/might be the reason" Missing hedging in academic writing: "proves that" → "suggests that" Over-hedging: "It seems that it appears that perhaps" → "It appears that" Wrong boosting adverb: "very proves" → "clearly proves" Flag Only: Lack of hedging in professional emails Collocation Errors Flag and Explain: Verb + noun: "do a mistake" → "make a mistake" Adjective + noun: "strong tea"
